Figure illustrating how pressure in a tire changes with added air and temperature. (a) When air is first pumped into a deflated tire, the volume increases significantly with little change in pressure. Expansion of a gas in a piston–cylinder system. A gas at pressure P pushes a piston of cross-sectional area A upward by a distance d, increasing the volume by ΔV = A·d. The upward force on the piston is F = P·A, and heat Q_in is added to the gas to maintain constant pressure during expansion. The diagram shows that the work done by the gas on the piston is W_out = F·d = P·A·d = P·ΔV, illustrating pressure–volume work for a constant-pressure process.

the first law of thermodynamics for a system. Heat Q enters or leaves the system, and work W is done by or on the system. The change in internal energy is shown as ΔU = Q − W, where Q represents the net heat transfer into the system and W represents the net work done by the system. Arrows indicate heat flowing into and out of the system (Q_in and Q_out) and work done by the system (W_out) or on the system (W_in), emphasizing energy conservation through heat and work transfers.

the first law of thermodynamics to biological systems. (a) A human body is shown as a system where food energy enters, increasing internal energy, while heat Q is transferred out and work W is done by the body, reducing internal energy. The relationship is expressed as ΔU = Q − W + food energy, illustrating metabolism as an energy balance. (b) A plant receives energy from the Sun as heat input Q_in, stores part of this energy as chemical (food) energy, and releases some energy as heat Q_out, showing how plants convert solar energy into stored internal energy.

Two energy-flow diagrams showing that different processes can result in the same change in internal energy. In (a), 15 J of net heat enters the system while 6 J of net work is done by the system, giving a change in internal energy of ΔU = Q − W = 9 J. In (b), 150 J of heat leaves the system while 159 J of work is done on the system, also producing ΔU = 9 J. The diagrams illustrate that if a system starts in the same initial state, different combinations of heat transfer and work can lead to the same final state and the same change in internal energy.

Examples of one-way (irreversible) processes in nature. (a) Heat flows spontaneously from a hot region to a cold region, shown by heat Q moving from hot to cold, but the reverse does not occur without external work. (b) A moving car slows to rest as its brakes convert kinetic energy into internal energy, which is then transferred as heat to the surroundings; the reverse process does not happen spontaneously. (c) A puff of gas released into a vacuum rapidly spreads out to form a uniform distribution, and the random motion of gas molecules prevents the gas from spontaneously re-collecting into one region.

Ice-to-water entropy increase diagram. On the left, ice is shown as an ordered structure with molecules arranged in a regular lattice. An arrow labeled ΔS > 0 points to the right, where liquid water is shown with molecules moving randomly in many directions. The diagram illustrates that when ice melts into water, molecular order decreases, disorder increases, and entropy increases due to heat transfer into the system.

Gas–piston system illustrating energy transfer and work. (a) Heat Q_in is added to a gas in a cylinder, increasing its internal energy ΔU and raising pressure, which produces a force F = P·A on the piston. (b) The gas expands, pushing the piston outward by a distance d and doing work W_out = F·d; during expansion, the gas’s internal energy decreases. (c) Heat Q_out is transferred from the gas to the surroundings, further lowering pressure so a smaller opposing force F′ is needed to move the piston back inward, with work W_in = F′·d.

Heat transfer and heat engine diagrams used in thermodynamics to illustrate the second law of thermodynamics and the basic operation of heat engines. (a) Heat flows spontaneously from a hot reservoir at temperature T_h to a cold reservoir at temperature T_c. (b) A heat engine operates between these reservoirs, absorbing heat Q_h from the hot reservoir, converting part of it into useful work W, and releasing the remaining heat Q_c to the cold reservoir, with W = Q_h − Q_c. The diagram provides a conceptual framework for understanding energy conversion limits and efficiency in real engines.

a simple heat pump system used for heating buildings. The cycle includes four main components: (1) an evaporator outside the building, where the working fluid absorbs heat Q_c from the colder outdoor air and evaporates; (2) a compressor that increases the pressure and temperature of the vapor; (3) a condenser inside the building, where heat Q_h is released to the indoor space as the fluid condenses; and (4) an expansion valve that lowers the pressure and temperature of the fluid before it returns to the evaporator. The diagram illustrates how a heat pump transfers thermal energy from a cold outdoor environment to a warmer indoor space using mechanical work.

Heat pump (reversed heat engine) diagram illustrating how refrigerators and air conditioners operate. The system absorbs heat Q_c from a cold reservoir at temperature T_c and, with the input of external work W, transfers a larger amount of heat Q_h to a hot reservoir at temperature T_h. Arrows show heat being pumped from cold to hot against the natural direction of heat flow. The diagram provides an academic illustration of the second law of thermodynamics applied to cooling devices, emphasizing that work is required to move heat from a cooler region to a warmer one.

Transverse wave on a toy spring. A person moves her hand up and down, creating a vertical disturbance in the spring while the wave travels horizontally to the right. Arrows indicate the direction of wave propagation, showing that particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of energy transfer. This academic diagram contrasts transverse waves with longitudinal waves, where the disturbance is parallel to the direction of propagation.

Longitudinal wave on a toy spring. A person pushes and pulls the spring horizontally, creating regions of compression and rarefaction that move to the right. The arrows show the direction of wave propagation v_w, which is the same as the direction of particle motion. This academic diagram illustrates a longitudinal (compressional) wave, where the disturbance is parallel to the direction of energy transfer.

Comparison of transverse and longitudinal waves using sound and strings. A guitar string vibrates up and down, demonstrating a transverse wave where the string’s motion is perpendicular to the direction of wave travel. An amplifier and speaker produce sound waves that travel outward through the air as longitudinal waves, shown by compressions and rarefactions. A sheet of paper and a handheld tuning fork vibrate back and forth in the same direction as the sound propagation, illustrating that sound waves in air are longitudinal, while waves in solids and water can have both transverse and longitudinal components.

Water wave diagram illustrating key wave properties. The horizontal distance between successive crests is labeled as the wavelength λ. The vertical distance from the equilibrium (dashed) line to a crest or trough is the amplitude X, with a total peak-to-trough height of 2X. The wave propagates horizontally along the water surface at speed v_w, while individual water particles move up and down rather than traveling with the wave.

Speaker diagram illustrating the relationship between frequency and wavelength for sound waves. The small speaker (tweeter) produces high-frequency sound with a short wavelength λ, shown by closely spaced wavefronts. The large speaker (woofer) produces low-frequency sound with a longer wavelength, shown by widely spaced wavefronts. The diagram emphasizes that in a given medium where wave speed is constant, higher frequency corresponds to shorter wavelength and lower frequency corresponds to longer wavelength.

Constructive interference of waves diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2), each with amplitude X and the same wavelength, are shown aligned in phase so that their crests and troughs occur at the same positions. When the waves overlap, their displacements add, producing a resultant wave with twice the amplitude (2X) and the same wavelength. The diagram illustrates pure constructive interference, where wave amplitudes combine to increase the overall displacement without changing the wavelength.

Destructive interference of waves diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2) with the same wavelength and amplitude X are shown exactly out of phase, so the crest of one wave aligns with the trough of the other. When the waves overlap, their displacements cancel at every point, producing a resultant wave with zero amplitude. The diagram illustrates pure destructive interference, where complete cancellation occurs due to opposite displacements.

Superposition of nonidentical waves diagram. Wave 1 and Wave 2 have different wavelengths and amplitudes and overlap in the same region of space. When combined, the resulting wave shows a complex pattern with some regions of increased amplitude (constructive interference) and other regions of reduced amplitude (destructive interference). The diagram illustrates that most real wave interactions produce mixed interference rather than pure constructive or pure destructive cancellation.

Standing wave formation diagram. Two identical waves (Wave 1 and Wave 2) travel in opposite directions and overlap. Their superposition produces a standing wave (Resultant) with fixed points called nodes, where the displacement is always zero, and antinodes, where the displacement is maximum. The pattern does not travel through space but oscillates in place due to alternating constructive and destructive interference at specific locations.

Standing wave on a string diagram. A string fixed at both ends oscillates in its fundamental mode, forming a single loop between the supports. The ends are nodes, where the displacement is zero, and the center of the string is an antinode, where the displacement is maximum. The length of the string L corresponds to half a wavelength, labeled λ₁, illustrating the relationship between string length, wavelength, nodes, and antinodes in standing waves.

Higher harmonics of a standing wave on a string. Two examples show a string fixed at both ends oscillating with multiple loops. Nodes are points along the string that remain stationary, while loops (antinodes) are regions of maximum displacement. In the second harmonic (left), the string contains two loops and an additional node, with wavelength λ₂ related to the string length L. In the third harmonic (right), the string contains three loops and more nodes, with a shorter wavelength λ₃. The diagram illustrates how increasing the number of nodes corresponds to higher harmonics and shorter wavelengths in standing waves.

Reflection of a wave pulse from a fixed end. An incident pulse travels along a string toward a rigid, fixed boundary. Upon reaching the fixed end, the pulse reflects and becomes inverted, meaning the crest turns into a trough as it travels back in the opposite direction. The diagram illustrates that reflection at a fixed end causes a phase inversion, whereas reflection at a free end would not invert the pulse.

Sound wave generation diagram. A vibrating string moves to the right, compressing the air in front of it to create a region of compression and expanding the air behind it to create a region of rarefaction. These alternating compressions and rarefactions propagate through the air as a longitudinal sound wave, illustrating how mechanical vibrations in a source produce sound.

Sound wave formation from a vibrating string. As the string moves to the left, it pushes air particles together on one side, creating a region of compression, while particles on the opposite side move apart, forming a region of rarefaction. The alternating compressions and rarefactions propagate outward through the air as a longitudinal sound wave, demonstrating how oscillating motion of a source generates sound.

Sound wave produced by a vibrating string. Alternating regions of compression and rarefaction propagate outward through the air after repeated vibrations of the source. The lower graph shows gauge pressure versus distance x, oscillating above and below zero, where zero represents atmospheric pressure. Positive pressure corresponds to compressions and negative pressure corresponds to rarefactions, illustrating that sound waves consist of small pressure variations around atmospheric pressure.

Sound waves entering the ear. Alternating compressions and rarefactions travel up the ear canal and strike the eardrum. Changes in air pressure exert a force on the eardrum, given by F = P·A, causing it to vibrate. These vibrations are transmitted through the middle and inner ear and converted into nerve signals that the brain interprets as sound.

Sound wave propagation from a vibrating source. A tuning fork oscillating at frequency f produces alternating compressions and rarefactions that travel outward symmetrically in all directions at wave speed v_w. The spacing between successive compressions defines the wavelength λ. The diagram illustrates the fundamental wave relationship between speed, frequency, and wavelength, emphasizing that in a given medium the speed of sound is approximately independent of frequency.

Graphs comparing sound waves of different intensities. Both graphs show gauge pressure P_g versus position x. The top graph represents a low-intensity sound with small pressure variations around zero, produced by a source with small-amplitude vibrations. The bottom graph represents a high-intensity sound with much larger pressure maxima and minima, produced by larger-amplitude vibrations. The diagram illustrates that greater sound intensity corresponds to larger pressure variations and stronger forces on objects the sound encounters.

Anatomy of the human ear showing the outer, middle, and inner ear. The outer ear includes the pinna and ear canal, which collect and direct sound waves to the eardrum. The middle ear contains the eardrum and oval window, where sound pressure is converted into mechanical vibrations and amplified. The inner ear includes the cochlea, cochlear duct, and round window, where vibrations are transformed into nerve signals sent through the cochlear nerve to the brain. The semicircular canals and vestibule are also shown and are responsible for balance, while the Eustachian tube helps equalize pressure.

Inner ear and middle ear anatomy showing how sound is converted into nerve signals. Sound travels through the ear canal and vibrates the eardrum (tympanum), which moves the three middle-ear bones: the hammer (malleus), anvil (incus), and stirrup (stapes). The stapes presses on the oval window, creating pressure waves in the fluid of the cochlea. These waves move the tectorial membrane and bend the cilia in the organ of Corti, stimulating auditory nerves that send signals to the brain. The round window allows fluid movement, and the Eustachian tube helps equalize pressure in the middle ear.

Sound waves radiating from a stationary source. A car emits sound that spreads outward as concentric spherical wavefronts. Observers X and Y, standing at equal distances on opposite sides, receive the sound with the same wavelength and frequency. The diagram illustrates that when the source, observers, and air are all stationary, sound propagates uniformly in all directions.

Sound waves emitted by a moving source illustrating the Doppler effect. A car moving to the right emits sound waves that spread out from successive positions labeled 1 through 5. Wavefronts are compressed in front of the car toward observer Y, producing a shorter wavelength and higher observed frequency, and spread out behind the car toward observer X, producing a longer wavelength and lower observed frequency. The diagram shows how motion of the source changes the observed sound depending on the observer’s position.

Sound waves from a stationary source illustrating the Doppler effect due to moving observers. A car emits sound waves that spread out uniformly as concentric circles. Observer Y moves toward the source and encounters wave crests more frequently, resulting in a higher observed frequency. Observer X moves away from the source and encounters wave crests less often, resulting in a lower observed frequency. The diagram shows that relative motion between the observer and the source changes the observed frequency even when the source is stationary.

Resonance illustrated with a paddle ball on a rubber band. The finger moves the support at different driving frequencies. At low frequency and high frequency, the ball oscillates with a small amplitude because energy transfer is inefficient. When the driving frequency matches the natural frequency f₀ of the ball–rubber band system, resonance occurs and the oscillation amplitude increases dramatically to about 2X. The diagram demonstrates that resonance produces maximum response when the driving frequency equals the system’s natural frequency.

Beats produced by wave superposition. Two waves with slightly different frequencies f₁ and f₂ and corresponding wavelengths λ₁ and λ₂ overlap in time. The waves alternate between destructive interference, where their amplitudes partially cancel, and constructive interference, where their amplitudes add. The resulting wave shows a periodic increase and decrease in amplitude over time, illustrating the beat phenomenon caused by the small difference in frequencies.

acoustic resonance in an air column closed at one end. A vibrating tuning fork generates sound waves that travel down the tube, reflect off the closed end, and interfere with incoming waves. At specific frequencies, this interference produces standing waves in the air column, leading to resonance where the sound amplitude is significantly increased.

a sound wave traveling through an air-filled tube that is closed at one end. A tuning fork at the open end generates a pressure disturbance that moves into the tube, then reflects off the closed end and travels back toward the opening. This reflection sets up conditions for standing waves and resonance in the air column, a key concept in acoustics and wave behavior in closed tubes.

resonance in an air-filled tube closed at one end, where a tuning fork produces a sound wave that travels into the tube and reflects from the closed end; when the tube length is such that the reflected wave returns half a cycle later, it interferes constructively with the incoming wave to form a standing wave with an antinode at the open end and a node at the closed end, demonstrating resonance in closed air columns studied in acoustics and wave physics.

a standing-wave resonance in a tube closed at one end, where vibrations introduced near the closed end produce a standing wave with zero air displacement at the closed end and maximum displacement at the open end; the figure highlights that the tube length corresponds to odd multiples of one-quarter wavelength, illustrating higher resonant modes and harmonics in closed air columns studied in acoustics and wave physics.

the first overtone resonance in a tube closed at one end, where air displacement is zero at the closed end and maximum at the open end; the standing wave fits three-quarters of a wavelength within the tube length, producing a higher-frequency resonance characteristic of closed-pipe acoustics.

the fundamental mode and first three overtones for a tube closed at one end, where air displacement is zero at the closed end and maximum at the open end; each resonance fits an odd multiple of one quarter wavelength into the tube length L, with increasing frequency and decreasing wavelength for higher overtones, illustrating the harmonic structure of closed-pipe sound waves.

the fundamental mode and first three overtones for a tube open at both ends, where air displacement is maximum at both ends and nodes form inside the tube; each resonant mode fits an integer number of half wavelengths into the tube length L, producing harmonics with wavelengths decreasing and frequencies increasing proportionally with mode number.

an electromagnetic wave showing oscillating electric field (E) and magnetic field (B) vectors that are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of propagation, with both fields in phase and traveling at speed c away from an oscillating charge.

Caption: the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum showing how visible light fits between infrared and ultraviolet radiation. The visible spectrum is labeled by color from red to violet, with wavelengths decreasing from about 700 nm for red light to about 400 nm for violet light. The diagram illustrates that color is determined by wavelength, with longer wavelengths corresponding to red light and shorter wavelengths corresponding to violet light, and highlights that the boundaries between infrared, visible light, and ultraviolet are gradual rather than sharply defined.

Side-by-side diagrams comparing subtractive and additive color mixing. On the left, the subtractive color model for pigments shows cyan, magenta, and yellow overlapping to form darker colors, with all three combining to produce black due to absorption of light. On the right, the additive color model for light shows red, green, and blue overlapping to create brighter colors, with all three combining to produce white light, illustrating the fundamental difference between pigment mixing and light mixing.

Diagram comparing visible wavelength ranges perceived by humans, bees, and dogs along a wavelength axis from about 300 to 700 nanometers. Humans perceive visible light from roughly violet to red, bees can see ultraviolet light in addition to part of the visible spectrum but not red, and dogs perceive a narrower range of colors with reduced sensitivity to reds and greens. The figure illustrates that different species experience color differently because their eyes contain different types and numbers of photoreceptor cells.

Diagram illustrating thin-film interference in optics. An incident light ray strikes the top surface of a thin film with refractive index n2 between two media n1 and n3. Part of the light reflects immediately at the top surface (ray 1), while the rest refracts into the film, reflects off the bottom surface, and exits as ray 2. The two reflected rays travel different optical path lengths, causing constructive or destructive interference depending on the film thickness t, wavelength of light, and refractive indices. This phenomenon explains effects such as color patterns in soap bubbles and the reduction of glare by polarized sunglasses.

polarization of transverse waves using a rope analogy. In panel (a), the rope oscillates in a vertical plane, representing vertically polarized waves that can pass through a vertical slit. In panel (b), the rope oscillates in a horizontal plane, representing horizontally polarized waves that are blocked by a vertical slit. The diagram illustrates that polarization describes the direction of oscillation perpendicular to the direction of wave travel, and that filters or slits only transmit waves polarized in the same direction, a principle that also applies to light waves.

the inverse square law for electromagnetic radiation. A point source emits light that spreads outward uniformly, forming larger spherical surfaces as the distance from the source increases. At distances r, 2r, and 3r, the same amount of radiant energy is distributed over increasingly larger surface areas, causing the intensity or illuminance to decrease with distance. The diagram shows that as the radius of the spherical surface increases, the energy per unit area decreases proportionally to one over the distance squared, explaining why light appears dimmer the farther it travels from its source.

the ways light travels from a source to an observer. Light from the Sun travels through empty space to reach Earth and then continues through different media such as air and glass. In the scene, sunlight enters a window, where it partially transmits through the glass and partially reflects off surfaces before reaching a person’s eyes. The dashed and solid arrows represent straight-line paths of light rays, emphasizing that light propagates in straight lines unless it reflects or changes direction when moving between different materials.

illustrating the law of reflection. An incident light ray strikes a flat surface and reflects away symmetrically on the opposite side of a dashed line that represents the normal, which is perpendicular to the surface. The angle of incidence (θᵢ) is measured between the incoming ray and the normal, and the angle of reflection (θᵣ) is measured between the reflected ray and the normal. The diagram shows that these two angles are equal, demonstrating that light reflects so that the incident ray, reflected ray, and the normal all lie in the same plane.

Diagram showing diffuse reflection from a rough surface. Several parallel light rays strike an uneven surface, where each small section has a different orientation. As a result, the incoming rays are reflected in many different directions rather than one single direction. This contrasts with reflection from a smooth surface, where rays reflect uniformly. Diffuse reflection explains why rough objects are visible from many viewing angles but do not form clear mirror-like images.

image formation by a flat mirror. Light rays from a bottle reflect off the flat mirror and enter the observer’s eye, obeying the law of reflection where the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection. The reflected rays diverge, but when traced backward as dashed lines, they appear to originate from a point behind the mirror, forming a virtual image. The diagram shows that the image distance di behind the mirror is equal to the object distance do in front of the mirror, explaining why flat mirrors produce upright images that appear the same size as the object but cannot be projected onto a screen.

Comparison of concave and convex mirrors and their focal lengths. In the concave mirror (left), parallel incoming light rays reflect and converge at a focal point F located in front of the mirror, giving the mirror a positive focal length f. This converging behavior allows concave mirrors to form real or virtual images depending on the object’s position relative to the focal point. In the convex mirror (right), parallel rays reflect and diverge outward, appearing to originate from a focal point F located behind the mirror, which is indicated as a negative focal length. Convex mirrors always form virtual, upright, and reduced images because reflected rays never actually meet in front of the mirror.

Image formation for concave and convex mirrors. In (a), an object placed outside the focal point of a concave mirror reflects rays that converge in front of the mirror, forming a real, inverted image on the same side as the object. In (b), when the object is inside the focal point of a concave mirror, the reflected rays diverge and appear to originate from behind the mirror, producing a virtual, upright, and magnified image. In (c), a convex mirror reflects rays that always diverge, regardless of object position, so the image is always virtual, upright, and reduced, appearing behind the mirror.

a Schmidt–Cassegrain telescope illustrating how incoming parallel light from a distant object enters the telescope, reflects off the large concave primary mirror, then reflects from a smaller convex secondary mirror before being brought to focus at the focal plane near the observer’s eye. This folded optical path allows the telescope to have a long effective focal length while remaining physically compact. The design improves light-gathering power and image clarity, making it widely used in astronomical observations to view faint and distant objects such as planets, stars, and galaxies.

a car headlight or spotlight uses a parabolic mirror to control light direction. The bulb is placed at the focal point of the parabolic mirror, so light rays emitted in all directions reflect off the mirror and emerge as parallel rays. This produces a bright, focused beam that travels long distances without spreading out significantly. The same physical principle is used in solar collectors, where sunlight is reflected and concentrated at a focal point to produce heat for energy generation, demonstrating how mirror geometry controls light propagation and energy concentration.

Ray diagram illustrating image formation by a concave mirror and the variables used in mirror and lens calculations. The object is placed at a distance do from the mirror with height ho, while the image forms at distance di with height hi. Rays are drawn using standard construction rules: one ray travels parallel to the principal axis and reflects through the focal point F, another passes through the focal point and reflects parallel to the axis, and a third reflects symmetrically about the normal. These rays intersect to locate the image position and size. The focal length f characterizes the mirror’s curvature and determines how strongly it converges light. The relationships among do, di, and f are described by the mirror (lens) equation, which is used to predict image location and magnification in optical systems such as mirrors, lenses, telescopes, and cameras.

refraction at the boundary between water and air using a fish tank example. Light rays emitted from the fish bend as they pass from water into air because the speed of light changes between the two media. As a result, the rays follow different paths to the observer’s eye, making the fish appear to be in a different position than its true location. This apparent shift occurs because the brain assumes light travels in straight lines and traces the refracted rays backward into the water. Refraction depends on the indices of refraction of the two media and is governed by Snell’s law. This effect explains common optical illusions such as objects appearing closer or displaced in water and is important in applications like lenses, eyeglasses, microscopes, and underwater viewing.

a lawnmower analogy to explain refraction and Snell’s law. The image compares the behavior of a light ray crossing a boundary between two media with different refractive indices to a lawnmower moving from a sidewalk onto grass. In medium 1 (sidewalk), the mower moves faster, just as light travels faster in a medium with a lower refractive index. When the mower enters the grass (medium 2), one wheel slows down first, causing the mower to turn toward the perpendicular; similarly, when light enters a medium where it travels more slowly, it bends toward the normal. In the reverse situation, when moving from grass to sidewalk, the mower speeds up and turns away from the perpendicular, just as light bends away from the normal when it enters a faster medium. This analogy helps visualize how changes in wave speed cause refraction at a boundary and why the angle of refraction depends on the properties of the two media.

refraction and dispersion of light by a glass prism. In panel (a), a single wavelength (pure λ) enters the prism and bends at each glass–air boundary due to the change in speed of light inside the glass. Because only one wavelength is present, the light emerges as a single ray with a new direction. In panel (b), white light enters the prism and is separated into its component colors. This occurs because the index of refraction of glass depends on wavelength, so different colors travel at different speeds inside the prism and bend by different amounts. Shorter wavelengths (violet, around 380 nm) experience a larger refractive index and bend more, while longer wavelengths (red, around 760 nm) bend less. This wavelength-dependent bending is called dispersion and explains phenomena such as rainbows and the separation of colors in optical instruments.

how a rainbow is formed by sunlight interacting with a water droplet. Incoming sunlight enters the droplet and slows down, causing refraction at the air–water boundary. Because the index of refraction of water depends on wavelength, different colors bend by different amounts, with violet bending more than red. After entering the droplet, part of the light reflects off the inner back surface of the droplet. The reflected light then exits the droplet and is refracted a second time as it returns to air, increasing the separation of colors. As a result, red light exits at a larger angle relative to the incoming sunlight, while violet light exits at a smaller angle. When many droplets are present in the atmosphere, each droplet sends a specific color toward the observer, producing the circular arc of colors known as a rainbow.

refraction, the critical angle, and total internal reflection at the boundary between two media with different indices of refraction. In panel (a), a light ray travels from a medium with higher index of refraction (n1) into a medium with lower index of refraction (n2). Because light speeds up when entering the lower-index medium, the refracted ray bends away from the normal (the perpendicular to the surface). The angles of incidence and refraction are measured relative to this normal. In panel (b), the incident angle is increased until the refracted ray travels exactly along the boundary between the two media. This incident angle is called the critical angle, and at this angle the refracted angle is 90 degrees. In panel (c), the incident angle is greater than the critical angle, so refraction no longer occurs. Instead, all the light is reflected back into the original medium, a phenomenon known as total internal reflection. This effect is explained by Snell’s law and is the physical principle behind technologies such as fiber-optic cables and light guides.

how total internal reflection causes diamonds to sparkle. Light entering the diamond from air slows down and bends toward the normal because diamond has a much higher index of refraction than air. When the light reaches an internal surface of the diamond at an angle greater than the critical angle, it cannot refract out into the air. Instead, it undergoes total internal reflection and is reflected entirely back into the diamond. Because the critical angle for a diamond–air boundary is very small, most light rays striking the internal faces are totally reflected multiple times. Diamond facets are carefully cut so that these internally reflected rays are directed back out through the top of the diamond toward the observer. This trapping and controlled release of light increases brightness, intensity, and sparkle, which is why diamonds appear exceptionally brilliant compared to other gemstones.

binoculars use prisms and total internal reflection to redirect light toward the observer’s eyes. Light rays entering the binoculars travel into glass prisms, where they strike internal surfaces at angles greater than the critical angle. Instead of refracting out of the prism, the light undergoes total internal reflection, allowing it to be reflected efficiently without the energy loss that occurs with metallic mirrors. The prisms are arranged as corner reflectors, which reverse and reorient the image so it appears upright and correctly oriented to the viewer. This optical path also allows binoculars to be compact while maintaining a long effective light path for magnification. The same physical principle is used in fiber-optic cables, where light is guided through glass or plastic fibers by repeated total internal reflection, enabling high-speed transmission of data for internet, telephone, and cable television systems.

optical fibers guide light using total internal reflection. Each fiber consists of a central core with a higher index of refraction (n₁) surrounded by cladding with a lower index of refraction (n₂). When light enters the core at a suitable angle, it strikes the core–cladding boundary at angles greater than the critical angle, causing total internal reflection rather than refraction out of the fiber. As a result, the light is confined within the core and can travel long distances with very little loss. Even when the fiber bends, the light continues to reflect internally and follows the curved path, allowing signals to propagate around corners. This principle enables fiber-optic communication systems, which transmit data as pulses of light for internet, telephone, and cable networks, offering high bandwidth, low signal loss, and immunity to electrical interference.

a convex (converging) lens bends light rays and brings them to a focal point. Light rays that enter the lens parallel to the principal axis are refracted at both curved surfaces of the lens and converge at a single point called the focal point (F). The distance from the center of the lens to this focal point is the focal length (f), which is a key property of the lens and determines how strongly it bends light. Ray 2 travels along the axis and passes straight through the lens with minimal deviation, while rays 1 and 3 bend toward the axis due to refraction. The enlarged view on the right shows how refraction occurs at each surface according to Snell’s law, with different angles of incidence and refraction as the light enters and exits the lens. This behavior explains how convex lenses are used in devices such as cameras, microscopes, glasses for farsightedness, and the human eye to focus light and form clear images.

a concave (diverging) lens affects incoming light rays. Rays that enter the lens parallel to the principal axis spread outward after passing through the lens instead of converging. Because the rays diverge, they appear to originate from a focal point (F) located on the same side of the lens as the incoming light. For this reason, the focal length f is defined as negative for a diverging lens. Ray 2 travels along the axis and passes through the center of the lens with minimal bending, while rays 1 and 3 bend away from the axis due to refraction at both lens surfaces. The dashed lines indicate the apparent paths of the rays, not the actual light paths, and are used to locate the virtual focal point. The enlarged view illustrates how Snell’s law governs the change in direction at each surface, with different angles of incidence and refraction. Concave lenses are commonly used in applications such as glasses for nearsightedness, where they spread incoming light so that images focus correctly on the retina.

Ray 3 travels through the focal point on the object side of the lens and emerges parallel to the axis after refraction. The refracted rays intersect on the opposite side of the lens, forming a real inverted image. Caption: Figure 17.18 The diagram shows the function of a diffraction grating in a spectroscope. The diagram illustrates how diffraction enables the analysis of light by wavelength, allowing a spectroscope to identify the composition of a light source. At the same time, it highlights that diffraction is an inherent wave effect that can also limit image sharpness by spreading light rather than keeping it perfectly focused.
